subSense.def:
heard or
seen before; that you know
subSense.example:
The dog
wagged its tail as it heard its master's
familiar voice at the door

He looked
round the room, and saw a couple of fa-
miliar faces

subSense.def:
a group of
people who are related to each other, es-
pecially mother, father and children
subSense.example:
The Jones family are going on holiday
to Spain
He grew up in a big family

subSense.def:
a group of animals or plants which
are closely related
subSense.example:
Lions and tigers
are members of the cat family
subSense.note:
NOTE:
The plural is families. When family is
used to mean a group of people it can
take a singular or plural verb: The fam-
ily were out

subSense.def:
a very serious
lack of food

known to
many people, especially most people in
a place or country
subSense.example:
a famous depart-
ment store
He's a famous footballer
This tea shop is famous for its cakes

subSense.def:
a piece of equipment
for moving air to make people or things
cooler
subSense.example:
We put electric fans in the of-
fice to try to keep cool

subSense.def:
an enthusiastic
supporter of something or someone, e.g.
a team or a pop group
subSense.example:
There was a
crowd of fans waiting for him outside
the theatre

subSense.def:
to want to have
something
subSense.example:
I fancy an ice
cream -anyone else want one?

Do
you fancy sharing a taxi to the airport?

body.subSense:
2. to like someone in a sexual way ć I'm
sure that guy fancies you. (NOTE: fan-
cies -fancying -fancied)

subSense.def: attractive or decorated
subSense.example:
He wore a
fancy tie to the party

subSense.def: n t stk/ wonderful
subSense.example:
We
had a fantastic time on holiday

subSense.def: strange; like a dream
subSense.example:
His sto-
ries are full of fantastic creatures

subSense.def:
an invented sto-
ry
subSense.example:
Her story of meeting a rich man in
Paris was pure fantasy
subSense.note:
NOTE: The plu-
ral is fantasies

subSense.def: a certain distance away
subSense.example:
The railway station is not far from
here

How far away is Paris from Lon-
don?

The road was blocked by cars as
far as we could see

subSense.def:
used with com-
paratives to mean 'much'
subSense.example:
It is far
cheaper to go by bus than by train

Restaurant food is far nicer than the
food at college

body.subSense:
a long way
away; distant ć The shop is at the far
end of the High Street. (NOTE: far -far-
ther / fɑ ðə/ or further / f ðə/ -far-
thest / fɑ ðəst/ or furthest / f ðəst/)

subSense.def:
a price which you have to
pay for a journey
subSense.example:
Rail fares have been
increased by 10%

The tourist-class
fare is much less than the first class one

If you walk to work, you will save £5
a week on bus fares
subSense.note:
NOTE: Do not con-
fuse with fair

subSense.def: goodbye
subSense.example: It's time to say farewell

body.subSense:
(of an event) at which you say
goodbye ć We gave a farewell party for
our neighbours who were going to live
in Canada

subSense.def: not at all
subSense.example: The food here is far from cheap

subSense.def:
an area of land used for
growing crops and raising animals
subSense.example:
He
runs a pig farm

We're going to work
on a farm during the holidays

You
can buy eggs and vegetables at the farm
shop

subSense.def:
to grow crops or raise ani-
mals on a farm
subSense.example:
He farms dairy cattle
in Devon

subSense.def:
a person who man-
ages or owns a farm

the work of
managing a farm, e.g. growing crops or
keeping animals for sale

to make
someone very interested
very interesting
subSense.example:
A microscope gives
you a fascinating glimpse of life in a
drop of water

The book gives a fasci-
nating description of London in the
1930s

It was fascinating to hear her
talk about her travels in India

subSense.def:
the most popu-
lar style at a particular time
subSense.example:
It was the
fashion then to wear your hair very
short
She always follows fashion

subSense.def:
of a style which is popular at a partic-
ular time
subSense.example:
These loose trousers are re-
ally fashionable at the moment

subSense.def:
pop-
ular with rich or glamorous people
subSense.example:
She lives in the fashionable West End of
London

It's a fashionable restaurant
for film stars and journalists

subSense.def: quick
subSense.example:
I just love
driving fast cars

She was driving in
the fast lane of the motorway

subSense.def:
not
stopping anywhere
subSense.example:
This is the fast
train to London

subSense.def:
to show
a time which is later than the correct
time
subSense.example: Your watch is fast

subSense.def: quickly
subSense.example:
Walk faster if you want to
catch up with the children in front

Don't go so fast -you almost hit that
man on the zebra crossing

subSense.def:
tightly
fixed in a particular position
subSense.example:
The win-
dow was stuck fast and I couldn't open
it

subSense.def:
to eat nothing for religious or
health reasons
subSense.example:
Many people fast dur-
ing Lent
He fasted for a week

subSense.def:
to close or attach
something tightly
subSense.example:
Please fasten your
seatbelts

These shoes fasten with a
buckle

subSense.def:
an object
which fastens something such as a piece
of clothing

having too much flesh
or weighing too much
subSense.example:
Two fat men got
out of the little white car

You'll have
to eat less -you're getting too fat
He's fatter than me

subSense.def:
a part of
meat which is yellowish-white
subSense.example:
If you
don't like the fat, cut it off

subSense.def:
which causes
death
subSense.example:
There were three fatal accidents
on this road last year

subSense.def:
a man who has a son
or daughter
subSense.example:
Ask your father if he will
lend you his car

She is coming to tea
with her mother and father

subSense.def:
an object
which, when you twist it, lets liquid or
gas come out

the fact of making a
mistake or of being to blame for some-
thing going wrong
subSense.example:
It isn't my fault if
there's nothing in the fridge

It's all
your fault -if you hadn't stayed in bed
all morning we would be at the seaside
by now

subSense.def:
an instance of something not
working properly
subSense.example:
The invoice was
wrong because of a computer fault

The engineers are trying to mend an
electrical fault

subSense.def:
a mistake in serving
in tennis
subSense.example: He served two double faults

subSense.def:
not working
correctly or not made correctly
subSense.example:
The
lights are flickering -there must be a
faulty connection somewhere

subSense.def:
with
mistakes in planning or judgment
subSense.example:
a
faulty argument

subSense.def:
a friendly act
done to help someone
subSense.example:
Can I ask a fa-
vour -will you look after my bike while
I'm in the post office?

subSense.def:
approval or
popularity
subSense.example:
She tried to win the favour
of the committee

subSense.def:
to like or
prefer something
subSense.example:
The managers fa-
vour moving to a bigger office

subSense.def:
to
make things easier for someone
subSense.example:
The
conditions favour Australian bowlers

subSense.def: good

which
you like best
subSense.example:
Which is your favourite
TV programme?

subSense.def:
something
or someone you like best
subSense.example:
Which ice
cream is your favourite?

This game is
a favourite with the children

The
singer was a favourite in the fifties

subSense.def:
someone who is treated better than other
people by a particular person
subSense.example:
She was
always her father's favourite

subSense.def:
a copy of a document or
picture sent to someone using telephone
lines
subSense.example: Post it to me, or send a fax
Can you confirm the booking by fax?

subSense.def:
to send a document or picture by
telephone
subSense.example:
I will fax the design to you
or I will fax you the design as soon as it
is ready

subSense.def: the feeling of being afraid
subSense.example:
Fear of the dark is common in small
children
She has no fear of heights

body.subSense:
to be afraid of something (formal)
ć What do you fear most

subSense.def:
a very large meal for
a group of people, especially one eaten
to celebrate a special occasion

a spe-
cial religious day
subSense.example:
Today is the Feast of
St Nicholas

subSense.def:
an particularly difficult
act

one of many light
soft parts which cover a bird's body

a part of the face
such as the nose or mouth
subSense.example:
His unusual
features make him easy to recognize

subSense.def: an important part or aspect of something
subSense.example:
The main feature of the castle is its
huge tower

subSense.def:
an important story or ar-
ticle in a TV news programme or in a
newspaper
subSense.example:
a feature on nuclear pow-
er

Did you see the feature on St Pe-
tersburg?

subSense.def:
to have someone as
the main performer of a film, a TV pro-
gramme or a play
subSense.example:
The film featured
Charlie Chaplin as the tramp

The
circus features Russian clowns

subSense.def:
to
have something as the most important
part
subSense.example:
The tour features a visit to the
Valley of the Kings

The next pro-
gramme will feature a discussion be-
tween environmental experts

subSense.def:
to ap-
pear as the main actor in, or as the sub-
ject of a film or a TV programme
subSense.example:
She
has featured in many TV series

body.subSense:
the second
month of the year, between January and
March ć My birthday is in February. ć
He died on February 17th. ć We are
moving to new offices next February.
(NOTE: February 17th: say 'the seven-
teenth of February' or 'February the
seventeenth', or in US English 'Febru-
ary seventeenth'.)

subSense.def:
relating
to the central government of the United
States
subSense.example:
Most federal offices are in
Washington

Federal law is more im-
portant than state law

subSense.def:
relating to a
system where a group of states exist un-
der a central government
subSense.example:
the former
Federal Republic of Germany

subSense.def:
money paid to someone
such as a doctor or lawyer for work done
subSense.example: Private school fees are very high

The lawyer's fee for two days' work was
more than I earn in a month

body.subSense:
1. physically
weak, especially because of illness or
age ć He gave a feeble wave with his
hand. ć The voice on the phone sounded
feeble. (NOTE: feebler -feeblest)

subSense.def:
not strong or able to be seen or heard
well
subSense.example: She replied in a feeble voice

subSense.def:
to give food to a person
or an animal
subSense.example:
I'd better just feed the
baby before we go out

Could you feed
the cat while we're away?

body.subSense:
2. (of a baby
or young animal) to take milk from its
mother ć Please don't disturb the baby
while she's feeding. (NOTE: feeds -
feeding -fed /fed/ -has fed)

subSense.def:
information
or comments about something which
has been done

to touch something, usu-
ally with your fingers
subSense.example:
Feel how soft
the bed is

subSense.def:
to seem soft, cold, etc.,
when touched
subSense.example: The bed feels hard
The stone floor felt cold

body.subSense:
3. to experi-
ence something with your body or mind
ć Did you feel the table move? ć I felt
the lift go down suddenly. ć Do you feel
warmer now that you've had a cup of
tea? ć They felt happy when they saw
that all was well. ć By twelve o'clock
she was feeling hungry. (NOTE: feels -
feeling -felt /felt/ -has felt)

subSense.def:
something which
you think you know
subSense.example:
I had a feeling
that this strange man knew who I was

subSense.def: someone's emotions
subSense.example:
I didn't
want to hurt her feelings.
